user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				 struct metal_device *device,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg,
				 int nents)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;
	(void)dir;

	for (i = 0; i < nents; i++) {
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg[i].virt, sg[i].len);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
void metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				 struct metal_device *device,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg,
				 int nents)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment does not call any functions from <string.h> (e.g., memcpy, memset, strcpy, strlen, etc.), so MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is not applicable. The loop simply calls metal_cache_invalidate(sg[i].virt, sg[i].len) for i = 0..nents-1. (Note: if metal_cache_invalidate internally used string.h functions and misused its parameters, that would be a separate issue, but that is outside the scope of the shown fragment.)
